questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Front Door instance named FD that contains an origin group named OG1.

You need to configure a health probe for OG1. The solution must minimize the amount of traffic generated by the health probe.

Which HTTP method should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Azure Front Door supports the following HTTP methods for sending the health probes:

GET: The GET method means retrieve whatever information (in the form of an entity) gets identified by the Request-URI.
HEAD: The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST NOT return a message-body in the response. For new Front Door profiles, by default, the probe method is set as HEAD.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/frontdoor/health-probes

Selected Answer: B
B - HEAD 
We do not care about what is retrieved, only about the server response. 
HEAD will return only the headers and the status code (the part that we care about)

Selected Answer: B
B is correct answear

Summary of the Azure Firewall rule types:
A. DNAT (Destination Network Address Translation):
Allows you to translate the destination IP address and port of incoming traffic to an internal IP address and port.
Primarily used to expose internal services to the internet.
Effectively, it maps a public IP/port to a private IP/port.
B. Network Rules:
Control traffic based on source and destination IP addresses, ports, and protocols (TCP, UDP, ICMP).
Used for general network traffic filtering.
C. Application Rules:
Control traffic based on fully qualified domain names (FQDNs), HTTP/HTTPS protocols, and other application-specific attributes.
Provides more granular control over web traffic.
D. Infrastructure Rules:
These are rules that the azure firewall uses for its own internal operations.
These rules are used for things like the azure firewall reaching out to the internet for updates, or for other internal azure communications.
These rules are mostly managed by Microsoft.

Selected Answer: C
Azure Firewall supports Application Rules to filter outbound traffic based on FQDNs

You need to configure a solution to meet the following requirements:

• App1 must be assigned a private endpoint.
• Access to App1 from the internet must be routed via FD1.

What should you configure on FD1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
By configuring an origin in FD1 that uses the Azure Private Link service, traffic from FD1 can reach the private endpoint of App1 securely.
Considering this is outbound traffic, an even better solution would be to replace the LB with a NAT gateway for outbound traffic.

Maximum Number of Ports:

The maximum number of ports available is determined by the number of frontend IP addresses and outbound rules.
Each frontend IP address in a Standard Load Balancer provides 64,000 SNAT ports.
Correct Selection: 128K

Since LB1 has two frontend IP addresses and each provides 64,000 SNAT ports, the total is 128K ports.
Increase the Number of SNAT Ports:

To increase the number of SNAT ports available, you need to add more frontend IP addresses because each frontend IP provides an additional 64,000 ports.
Correct Selection: Frontend IP addresses for LB1

Adding more frontend IP addresses to LB1 will increase the total SNAT port pool.
